title: Eachine Wizard X220 FPV Cam Lens spacer

description.text:
Like a lot of people I bought this 2.1mm lens for my x220 from banggood, only to realize that you have to remove the locking nut in order to get it to focus. This is simply a spacer to tighten your lens against. I have included both a 3mm and 3.25mm version depending on where you want the focus. Mine worked best with the 3mm but your experience may vary.

Should work with different camera/lenses, but the focus distance will probably be wrong.

author: sky_crab

description.text:
A friend of mine designed this as a Christmas present for his girlfriend. He was kind enough to let me put it on here, so thanks go out to Thomas Heidrich ;-)
The idea is to print the three parts separately and use the holes to connect them with screws, so you can paint the parts if you like. That's why the picture shows all different colours ;-)
The last file is all three parts in one .stl, but I didn't try that, should be possible though.

To be able to use screws, you should make the first 10-15mm full material, or at least use a big number of perimeters, so the holes are strong enough.
The volleyball somehow isn't really good slicable with slic3r, so if you make infill below 1, there will be completely filled parts in every slice. I realized this too late, so I just kept going. It did print without problems, but it's quite heavy now :)
You might want to fix orientation for the set with all parts together, so that the plate is at the bottom.

title: Smartphone Spectrometer for the Galaxy S4

description.text: I made this spectrometer to fit my Galaxy S4 phone after doing a class lab in spectrum of sources and diffraction. The pictures above are the spectra of the sun, actinic, 6700k, 10000k T5 bulbs, a Fluorescent bulb and a mercury vapor lamp. I used a free android app called SpectraUPB to plot the spectra but the calibration from pixels to wavelength is not perfect. A better free online spectrum analysis tool is at https://spectralworkbench.org/ or possibly try using matlab or gimp.

author: sky_crab

description.text:
A computer fan stand for a desk or similar. Suits a 200mm+ fan that has a width of 30mm.
There are 3 parts to this design, the bottom block, the middle blocks which you can use to give it adjustable height by adding more blocks (they are 2cm in height) and the top piece which you use a screw and nut to attach on the fan.

A small amount of filing may be required to fit the blocks together, once they are joined together (I used a hammer to help), they can be a little hard to take out. You can use double sided tape to stick it on a desk otherwise it's too easy to slide around or just use 1 side of the double sided tape and the other side provides enough roughness that it doesn't slide around too easy.

Malyan M150

Resolution:

0.2

20

title: P4P Gimbal Lock for PolarPro Filters

description.text:
It is a gimbal lock similar to gimbal lock of genuine accessory of Phantom 4 Pro.
There are two kinds of lens covers for normal lens filter and PolaPro lens filter.
In order to use elasticity of plastic as a spring and also to be able to print without support as much as possible, the arm part and the lens cover part were separated into separate parts.

Printer:

Bonsai Lab. BS01

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I use plastic elasticity as a spring.
Therefore, please use ABS or a filament that has elasticity comparable to ABS rather than cheap PLA.

I use Polymakr PolyMAX™ PLA.

author: Migue_1987

description.text:
This design is from DANILO COVA from Como (Italy), one of the great Makers of our Community. He found the way not to trow away his used spools from FILOALFA - 3D filaments Italian producer - and re use them as desk organizer to store screws, bolts, small parts.
This simple and creative idea is so good that we decided to share it with you. Maybe you don't use this producer's filaments, but you can easily modify the design to fit the kind of spool you usually buy. Use some self-tapping screw to mount the drawers inside the spool.

IMPORTANT: you don't need to make holes in the spools, simply use the pre-existing holes near to the edge to insert the screws.
All the best!

title: RTk.GPIO Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A case for the RTk.GPIO.

Please note this is the first test, We're getting it modified to increase the slot where the header is to expose the GPIO Map. However if you want just the pins exposed then both parts are fine. If you prefer to wait for the other version then you can still print the bottom.

Prints in two parts and reasonably well. Case provides protection to prevent the board and pins from getting damaged by accident.

We've released the files for people to print themselves

Commercial use in the sense of a business or school printing them for themselves is fine. However only we are allowed to print and sell the cases.

Printer:

i3 Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

5% - My slicer didn't use any.

Notes:

Depending on layer height the time takes between 45 Minutes to 2 Hours. (0.3MM-0.1MM).

We printed it in 0.3 and the edges weren't as smooth as we liked. We found 0.2 had a good finish. 0.1MM will be better but takes 2-3 hours per layer.

a 1.2mm Wall is recommended.

Don't forget to rotate it to print with the bottom of the bottom layer and top of the top layer to be on the bed.
After printing put board into bottom part and push into place. Then push the top on and they should clip together.

tube_diameter = 12

This is my creation of a wind vane. I designed it, to use it on miiiike's Vertical Windmill Mk2, but it can be used as a stand-alone.

Allthough the Vertical Windmill Mk2 used carbon fibre rods, I used steel 4mm rods. In the tip of the vane, I use a 8mm rod.

For the bearings, I used 8x16x5(688ZZ) bearings from Banggood:
http://www.banggood.com/Wholesale-10Pcs-16mmx8mmx5mm-Steel-Shielded-Deep-Groove-Ball-Bearing-688ZZ-p-49911.html

I got the rods from my local construction market.
Assemble the wind vane accoring to the drawing.
The steel 8mm rod, in the tip of the vane, is for balancing the assembly. If the rod isn't in the tip, to much weight will lean on the tail section, causing the vane not to rotate smoothly.

Miiiike's Vertical Windmill Mk2
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:948401

comments.text: So bummed, I bought these plans after looking at all the various choices, printed the whole fuselage, came out awesome. Then I went to print the floats and sure enough, I missed the fine print about the print bed requirements on this one being quite a bit bigger than the other plans. I can see the big wing piece is too big as well.+ I can get a glass setup and do 8X10, that covers me on the X and Y but there's not much I can do with the Z axis other than creating another slice/glue line which is what I'll have to do at some point so I can finish this one. Head down, I grabbed the Spitfire plans and am half way through printing that one, it's coming out amazing and that one fits my bed just fine!

This steampunk bong is based on the steampunk bong from CreatorLes: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:275541 It's not really a remix but I designed it from scratch using FreeCad because I wasn't able to load his stl-files.

The item shown was printed with copper PLA.

This is a housing for the Wemos D1. It's for the big board, not the mini!

The box has four pins to attach the Wemos board, I've printed and tested with a MakerBot Replicator Mini+ and you can gently push the board over the pins and it sits tight.

The lid comes in a few flavors.

  1. Just the lid with a reset button hole
  2. The lid with a reset button hole and DHT22 hole cut-out.

TODO: This thing is a work in progress. What I still want to do is to make some kind of tube above the led to have the led output only through that single hole in the lid.

remixed_from.title: Z-probe holder for Makerfarm i3 with auto bed-level

description.text:
A mount for a z-axis servo to a x-carriage. This is not specific to any carriage. I just drilled a couple of holes to mount it on the carriage. The scad file is set for a Temco CN0097 micro switch. It's offset to have the roller inline with the pivot. 1/25/2014
Updated the servo mount scad file to make one that can fit a fan mount. Also, the z stop servo mount has been changed to shift the switch part to either side of the horn. 2/23/2014
Made the z stop servo mount thicker (4mm).
Added countersinks to the mounting holes for the servo, the mounting screw would obstruct the lever.

Print them.  Trim the arm to fit the servo horn. Mount a Temco CN0097 with two 3mm screws.  Drill two 2.5mm holes to mount the servo holder onto the carriage with two 3mm screws.  Make sure the servo mounting screws are not interfering with the arm.  Then modify the appropriate items in Marlin to use. I used a Hitec HS-65HB servo. The scad files are partially parametric. I recommend using a 7805 to supply 5v power to the servo.  For the RAMPS, the Mega 2560's 5v regulator is near it's limit.

comments.text: integrate your servo mount into an x-carriage design and I would use it in a heartbeat. I don't want to drill and mount separate pieces.into the xcarriage I have right now.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16627 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=16627

Using the following options: idler = 1

nut_angle = 90

Tired of moving your 3D printer to get and remove the filament drips under the heatbed ?
I was so used Tinkercad to design these easy to remove and empty drip trays for the want of a better name.
These 10 and 15mm deep trays take around 3 to 4 hours to print depending on the layer height and speed of printing. This is based on .2 layer height and 40mm per second.

There are 3 different types here. First is the straight 180x150mm. These you will need two of them. Just slide them both sides of the heatbed. Then there is the shaped drip trays.
First is the drip trays that fit around the front brace which I printed using this design http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1430727

Lastly is the left hand side which was shortened to fit around the cable chain which is this one.

remixed_from.title: Replacement air filter of roomba 760 of IRobot

description.text:
This is replacement air filter for Roomba 8xx & 9xx.
Remix of: Replacement air filter of roomba 760 of IRobot by alfredosanz

Printing BODY:
No special instructions

Printing LID:
Skin Thickness: 0mm / Don't print solid top and bottom!
Perimeters: 3 - 5
Variable infill. Recommended 20% - 33%

Printing MESH:
Skin Thickness: 0mm / Don't print solid top and bottom!
Perimeters: 3 - 5
Variable infill. Recommended 33%

Differences:
Resized "UP" part, now it fit's without bending filter door.
It's necessary to peel of foam seal from old filter and stick it to "LID" part. This prevents from micro dust entering propeller.

comments.author: Shmilcat

comments.text:
Thank you for the kind words!
I have been thinking about that, I have some ideas on how to to make it really good. Hopefully I'll have time to do it soon!
comments.author: Shmilcat

comments.text: I'm VERY new at printing. But if you print this in a single file won't it come out as a single piece with nothing about to move within?  Sorry if this is a really dumb question.
comments.author: KenatSunrise

comments.text:
If you print this with the flat side down, it shouldn't come out as a single piece. It is a gap between the different parts on every layer, so they never fuse together.
If you want to see how it works, I suggest that you check out the file in Curas layer view mode: https://ultimaker.com/en/resources/16584-view-modes
comments.author: KenatSunrise

comments.text: Awesome, I can't wait to try this.
comments.author: filiptheking

comments.text: Fantastic design thank you, what would be a practical application, wheels for a mobile cabinet?
comments.author: ceccuz

comments.text:
Thank you!
I guess it could be used in similar ways as regular spherical bearings are used. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spherical_bearing.
I don't think it would be very good as wheels for a mobile cabinet though. The outer ring has too much freedom of movement for this bearing to be used as wheels. However, I could maybe be used as bearings for wheels, but you would need two bearings for each wheel.

A Very simple heart from SCAD then extruded.

I printed it in transparent (natural) PLA and made it hollow because the completed model has an ATTiny85 controlling a RGB led through the HSV color scale.

I will upload video once I can take it out of hiding (post 14th).
if people want the simple schematic and HEX can be uploaded as well.

The small square hole in the back is for the switch to turn the electronics on/off. If you are not intending to add the electronics you can safely print 2 of the solid side.

simple SCAD code (attached as well)

heart() {
square(20);
translate([10,20,0])
circle(10);
translate([20,10,0])
circle(10);
}
heart();

but I decided it wasn't enough. I created it as a sketch in Fusion and applied an edge to round it. then modeled a simple base.

title: 3DLabPrint Spitfire XVI Accessories
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here a some accessories for the 3DLabPrint Spitfire XVI.

Firstly is a Battery and balance weight holder. There are two versions depending on the thickness of your Lipo.

  • SpifireBatteryHolder1.STL - Thinner and lighter Lipos so more space for balance weight.
  • SpifireBatteryHolder2.STL - Thicker and heavier Lipo with less balance weight capacity. It can take up to a Turnigy Graphene 2200mAh 65C.

Depending on the length of your Lipo you might want some longer battery clips.

  • SpitfireBatteryClip6.STL - This clip is 6mm longer than the standard one.
  • SpitfireBatteryClip10.STL - This one is 10mm longer.

To help keep the weight as far forward as possible I designed a clip (SpitfireESCRetainer.STL) to hold the ESC as far forward as the reciever cable and space would allow.

Finally its second landing the tail broke off at the glue joint behind the cockpit. To prevent this I designed a joint doubler (Spitfire_XVI_fuselage_5-Bulkhead.STL) to increase the glue area and assist with alignment. I've also included a Simplify3D factory file with my settings for this part.

The photo of the fuselage front half looks like its suffering from camera shake, but It's actually showing the joint doubler in place.

Printer:

Cherry Pi IIIs with DuetWifi

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I printed these parts with three perimeters and three top and bottom solid layers to prevent generation of infill on the thin walls.

The part Spitfire_XVI_fuselage_5-Bulkhead.STL should be printed with one shell, zero infill and no top and bottom solid layers.

comments.text: Thanks for designing the fuselage reinforcement for the section 4/5 joint. I kind of dropped mine on the nose a bit on the second landing and the fuselage let go at this joint. Rebuilding due to some damage in the nose as well.

This was a 7th grade science project. Students research and wrote a report about a prehistoric animal and created a 3D model of the animal. Students were encourage to choose a less familiar animal instead of the usual dinosaurs seen in Jurassic Park movies (T Rex, Velociraptor, etc.).

Many of the models will need support to print. Some of the 2 legged models are not balanced - now we know why dinosaurs needed big long tails! Models are not to scale.
NGSS

This project came near the end of a unit about Earth's geologic history.  The students had just completed a computer coding project using scratch.mit.edu in which they created an animated story about a past geologic era.  In this project they chose one animal from the past and wrote a short report on the animal and created a 3D model of the animal.

• Students first chose an animal from the past as the subject for their project. Many students chose one from an earlier project they has completed. I also provided a list of unfamiliar animals they could choose, but they weren't required to pick from that list (see PDF assignment sheet).

  • Students researched their animal and wrote a short report about their animal (see assignment sheet and student example).

  • Students used Tinkercad to design a 3D model of their animal. Very little instruction was needed because they had already completed a similar assignment about an endangered species: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1851360

  • Students shared their completed reports and models with their classmates
Only a 3D printer and some filament. For research the students can use the Internet or books from the library.

These are flex material printed 8MM rod mounts. they assist is helping to dampening the noise of the Y bed movement on most i3 type printers with a 2020 frame setup as well as possibly on other frames with 2020 extrusions.
Obviously the yellow is flex and the red (clamp) are PLA or what ever you choose

It does help, but it's not the end all to noise. But they do lower the amount of vibrations transferred through to the frame while not adding slop to the carriage or it's movement.

comments.text: One of the main cause of the poor quality of these printers is the lack of rigidity. You just make it worse. If you want to get rid of the noise, get proper bearing and smooth rods.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: Actually, you are very much wrong. Yes lack of rigidity is an issue with these types of printers but lack of vibration dampening is just as bad as a loose or a wobbling frame.  Since the addition of these clamps the quality of my prints have increased if anything. the flex filaments with this design has little or no movement and if anything the rods are more stable. the only thing these do is dampen vibration. Vibration can and will cause ribbing and other artifacts in prints. Reason you'll see more and more people using the dampeners on the motors which can cause much more alignment issues than these simple rubber clamps can.  Also the reason any high precision piece of engineered machinery will have some sort of dampeners for the motion systems, Harmonic dampening actually makes motion systems more accurate.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
I modified my Prusa to get rid of all vibration. I doubt your "dampener" behaves like an harmonic dampener (I use them on my compound bow BTW) ! Dampeners are used as a last resort when you can't do otherwise (piston engine ). Always better to eliminate the cause of the problem instead of compensating for it.
Anyway by looking at your machine, plenty of other things that are not OK. So spare me the "you are wrong".

description.text:
Found this amazing design by davinci85, thought i would utilize his design.
If you are like me, i always charge my phone next to my bed, half of the time i either find the cable on the floor, or worse.. at the back of the [email protected](*%$&

Here are some background information.

Cable: Factory Nexus 5x/6p cable(4 mm diameter)
magnet: 3 x 10 mm disk neodymium
scaling calculation: ((4+1.5)-(3+1.5))/((3+1.5))+1 = 1.2222

Since the original from davinci85 was for lightning cable(3 mm diameter), i had to scale it by 1.2222 to make it fit on the nexus cable(1.5 mm was the clearance in the original design).

Now just glue a piece of magnet on your nightstand/headboard to hold your charger cable.

Let me know if you want me to update for different cable diameter or magnet sizes, i will try to upload them.

title: Anet A8 monolith frame plus new braces and all printer parts refined

description.text:
Published files are fully usable, but some new improvements are coming...

This started as an idea to make one piece main frame for Ane A8 to replace the two pieces wobbling stock frame, but in the dimensions verifying process I realized that it would be much better to model all the printer parts. Apart from the obvious main improvement - the new front frame, some errors In the original stock version has been fixed and some further improvements were made. All parts should be backwards compatible, meaning they should be capable of mixing with the stock parts.

Update 20.02.2017

The frame and the other printer parts should be pretty finished. I will be laser cutting it in the next days, will post the result.

Few words about the frame versions.

The first frame version is a one piece version of the stock design. The display mount inside the frame. I added two columns of extra slots at the top on the sides of the display for mounting optional accessories (spool holders, filament guides, etc...). If cutting this version it is a good idea to use the two fixers as shown on one of the enclosed pictures to fix the middle section of the vertical trapezoid stock braces to the frame. These fixers are included in the "minimal cut" dxf file. In this file there are some other parts included. Cutting those should minimally increase the cost as they are positioned inside the main frame.

The second design differs from the first in the top. The top of the frame is used for slots for accessories and option. In this case the display is mounted on top of the frame (or anywhere else) using the enclosed mounting plate and holder. There is a freedom where to put it - from the left to the right side of the frame. There are two versions of this mount, use whichever you like more. I think the slimmer one looks better and is more flexible, leaving more of the accessories slots available. This version is included in the "full_set" file. This file includes all printer parts. If you do not want to print those, just delete what you don't need.

One tricky detail. The original stock "walls" of the z-motors cages are cut of 5mm acrylic. Supposedly nobody would cut those from 5mm, bu will do everything in one pass of 8mm. This is the reason why there is 8mm slots version of the frame and 5 mm slots version of the frame. The difference is at the slots for the z-motor cage. Respectively there are two versions of the z-motor mounting plates. Please pay attention and use what you need. I designed some simple inserts in case 8mm slots would be used with 5mm thick walls. The "full set" file includes 8mm versions.

For now, that's it. Hope you enjoy it.

Below is the older text:

This is first version of the one-part front Anet A8 frame. This should replace the two front frame parts, thus fully stabilizing the z-axis and completely eliminating the wobble. This part is to be cut from 8mm thick acrylic plate or similar material. The idea is to be fully compatible with the other parts. There are tho small braces to fit and stabilize the middle points of the perpendicular trapezoid braces. These small braces differ for the left and the right side. The holes should fit exactly above the holes in the trapezoid braces, so bolting there should not require drilling.
Please remember this is the very first version, and should be improved further.

I enclosed an stl file just to get the thing viewable within thigiverse, but of course it cannot be printed at least due to its size. Please, do not critisize ;-).

Another note to the FreeCad file - it is not cleaned up, so a bit messy inside, will fix it soon.

The fixation of the braces is shown on the picture with the orange and light blue braces above. There are 2 pairs of square slots for fixing the middle section of improved future version of the trapezoid braces. This are the light blue braces in the picture. The fixing of the stock braces (orange in the picture) goes through the slots pair which is not in line with the others using the additional fixers (coloured red).

Hello Makeitright,
yes I think it would be best to laser or water jet cutting the frame. I will try cnc milling at first. The question is how will the deviations reflect the dimensions. This is about to be seen.
Cleaned up the FreeCad file and corrected a small mistake in one of the fixers. Those can be cut or printed.
FreeCad file still includes several identical copies of the parts. The copies just have different 3d space location needed to display the assemblies, without rotating and moving the parts. If changing the design it is best to first delete those copies to have a single starting point.
Dxf file is as plain as possible, ready for cutting.
I uploaded a picture which shows the idea of the fixing of the braces. Should be easy to understand. The point was to have a future proof frame, capable of accommodating future improved versions of the trapezoid braces without the need to cut the frame again. Kind of incremental approach.
Thank you for the good words :-)

author: tzahov

print_settings.Notes:: All parts are printed at 100%. I maxed out resolution for the given diameter, so it is still sliceable in Simplify3D. Other slicers are able to scale it down, but you may get issues with very thin walls if you go too low. Also the lamp body will not fit, when using the projector without the lamp body it will work exactly as v2.

title: Customizable stereographic picture projector v3 highres

description.text:
Highres version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2078413
This allows using pictures with 85x85 pixels instead of 55x55, but it is also considerably bigger. I used these 10W power LEDs, here they come bundled with drivers: https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B01FZ5OWA8 and these coolers: https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B00NQA1U8C
The lamp is strong enough so the projection is even clearly visible in daylight, in the darkness of course it looks better.

Edit: It seems the customizer is not working, probably the complexity is too high as it is exactly the same code as the low res version which works. I will check if I can lower complexity a bit, until then you can locally create the thing with OpenSCAD. For this you need to scale the picture manually to 85x85 pixels and generate the image array with this script: http://jsfiddle.net/threonin/6dr8qu41/
Then you need to set the variable "part" first to "projector" and then to "lamp" and render both parts.

Edit: Made some small performance improvements by rewriting screw thread library to use a single polyhedron. Customizer seems to work again! Two test images worked that had failed before, if you are still having issues, let me know. Seems like some remixes went through, so it was probably very close to the timeout, now it should be faster by ~16%.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Notes:

All parts are printed at 100%. I maxed out resolution for the given diameter, so it is still sliceable in Simplify3D. Other slicers are able to scale it down, but you may get issues with very thin walls if you go too low. Also the lamp body will not fit, when using the projector without the lamp body it will work exactly as v2.

comments.text:
On the pictures it looks smaller than it actually is, I printed everything at 100%.
I'm using Simplify3D and not Cura, but the principles are the same. The time depends mainly on the layer height and the print speed, I used 0.3mm and 60mm/secs, if you use smaller layer height and slower speed it will take longer. Of course it depends on what your printer can handle. If you are new to 3D printing you should probably start with some easier prints until you know the basics and the common problems, when a very long running print fails this can be very frustrating, I also learned this the hard way.

Threonin- To say this is pretty awesome is an understatement. Nice work!
I made a custom one and it didn't turn out as I wanted. I published here for reference
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2125210
So, I am currently printing your Einstein version very slowly and at 0.2mm layer height and the max scale that will fit on the bed (90%)
I have a couple of debugging and set-up questions:
The customizer has an invert image button. I used it. (I'm used to inverting images when making lithophanes)
1) Am I supposed to invert the image if I want it to come out normal? As I decipher my projection, it makes me think "No"
2) Where is the light source supposed to be? at the center of the sphere, correct?
3) Are you using a deposition type printer or an SLA printer? Looking at the holes at the top of the sphere, makes me think that you have an SLA printer.
4) Is there an orientation feature somewhere? Thread starts at bottom or somesuch? Orientation is obvious when it works. I'm just wondering for debugging purposes.
You probably already answered these questions somewhere. Just point me at that and I will read up myself.
Dankeschön. -Joe
comments.author: joe_balint

comments.text: You definitely have to invert/mirror the image for correct projection! I'm a photographer and I can tell you that is a law of optics! Obviously you can't see in something symmetric but anything else, especially apparent with words or logos will be projected right to left if you don't mirror them first.
comments.author: joe_balint

comments.text:
Thank you! I will gladly answer your questions.
1) No, you are not supposed to invert the image. The brighter the pixel, the bigger the hole will be.
2) The light source is not at the center, but at the north pole. This design features a screw on lamp body that will hold an LED exactly in the right place. If you look at the sixth picture you will see the 10W LED chip mounted on a cooler. If you scale the design you will not be able to fit them anymore, a better idea would be to decrease inner and outer radius in the design and set cooler height and radius to the dimensions of the parts you have. I linked the parts I used in amazon.de, on amazon.com you can find them here: https://www.amazon.com/dp/B019DZ2122 , https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00NQ9NJCS
I had the issue that I could not slice the design anymore when scaling it down anymore, but if you already managed to decrease it to 90% I guess your slicer can handle it, I used Simplify3D.
3) No, I use two Flashforge Creator Pros. At the top the prints are not perfect, on my 2015 model there even was a slight hole, probably due to bad calibration: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2111102 . The prints on my 2016 model worked fine, only a bit of sanding on the inside and cleaning some of the holes with a small hex key or similar tool was required. I printed them with 0.3mm resolution and 60mm/sec.
4) Thread should be at the bottom, so the default orientation is correct. At least this is how I printed it. Any other orientation would not have a good contact with the build plate and require support. On the other hand flipping it may help with decreasing overhang angles and the center would probably be cleaner if the support comes off nicely. I did not include a feature to switch orientation in the script, would not be hard to do if it is needed.
comments.author: joe_balint

comments.text: You definitely have to invert/mirror the image for correct projection! I'm a photographer and I can tell you that is a law of optics! Obviously you can't see in something symmetric but anything else, especially apparent with words or logos will be projected right to left if you don't mirror them first.
comments.author: threonin

comments.text: True, the image is mirrored when projected. Didn't give it much thought, but for words or logos this would indeed be a problem. It is an easy fix tough. The original question was about the colors being inverted, which they should not be.

comments.author: Ryankimharrison

comments.text:
The problem is, if you scale it down, it probably will not slice anymore. I have been trying around for some time to get the maximum resolution for a given size so it still works with Simplify3D. Maybe with a smaller nozzle or another Slicer you can go lower than that. There are also some relevant settings in the scad file in the projector section, it is quite possible that there are better combinations than the one I found. As long as you can still slice it you can scale it all you want, but details may also go missing if your printer can't handle it, also the better option would be to decrease outer and inner radius settings, scaling the stl could lead to very thin walls, now they are at 1.5mm. Also for the lamp part the LED cooler would not fit anymore if you are using the one I linked, so changing settings with OpenSCAD or the Customizer is needed if you want to make it into a lamp. Currently the Customizer seems to have some issues, this is probably due to the complexity, so you would need to do it locally in OpenSCAD.
The easier option is to use the low resolution version which is much smaller: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2078413
Picture resolution and radius scale linear, so doubling the resolution makes it necessary to double the radius as well to keep the same level of detail. If the low res version does not have enough detail for you you could aim for something in between.

comments.text: Hi, the thing consists of multiple parts, the preview is selected by default so it does not break Customizer, rendering an accurate preview would time out and it is also not correctly displayed. When using the script locally you need to set the variable "part" to "projector" and "lamp" to get the respective part, Customizer automatically creates all of them. The 2D objects is just the text stating that it is just a preview, if it is not visible you are maybe on an older version, I am using 2015.03.

title: D-Bot Core_XY goes Linear (was: in Threes)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
• 3-wheeled or Linear Railed Modular X-carriage (D-Bot Core_XY 3D Printer) by
    printingSome, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2206664
    (11/1/17) This has gotten some extra possible setups, lately: Nimbles and a linear guide (MGN9(H)).
    Still the picture of it here is of bygone ages (thanks nandinho84), I hope to
    replace it in a not too distant future. See the link for how it is now... (still ;-) ).
  • I used the 3-wheeled Y guides (Re-D-Bot) by NickRimmer
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1930200
    which served me well, but I want to try linear guides, so made a remix:
    "3-wheeled Y guide goes linear" by printingSome
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2701748
  • For the Z-axis I now don't use any more wheels, but 2 ø12x600mm linear shafts with SCS12LUU Linear Ball Bearing Blocks etc. see "D-Bot_Linear_Z-guide by printingSome"
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2779260
  • 3-point supported bed

Most parts (and ideas, of course, thanks a lot!!) came from:

  • D-Bot Core-XY 3D Printer by spauda01
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001065
    with that very extensive and helpful documentation
  • J-Bot Core-XY? by JonnayLin
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1721957

but also:

  • Lead_Screw_Bracket (Self-Adjusting) by printingSome
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2664656
  • Beefed-up Corner for D-Bot / 20mm V-Slot Rails by beepbeep
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1605514
  • Ramps 1.4 Enclosure for Vslot, a bit bigger by printingSome,
    a new leaner version since 9/13/17, not in the picture here, see:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2053035
  • Ball_Foot for D-Bot by printingSome
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2057063
  • RepRapDiscount Full Graphic Smart Controller by Trigubovich
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1116163
    for which I made some V-slot supports.
  • 325x325mm bed support for J-Bot Core-XY? by printingSome
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1845327
    Not really necessary any more, now the front V-slot bar has disappeared, but
    still gives a little more room for moving the bed.

One can buy a cheap but beautiful cover for the Solid State Relay, which covers all the isolated parts and leaves the hot spots open for the world to enjoy. ;-(
It seemed better for my health to make a less inviting cover.

Having had bad experiences in the past with E3D fan mounts (my fault undoubtedly), I bought a very cheap injected moulded fan housing guard and added a conversion for a bigger fan to it. Needs supports, so I made a version with home made ones. ;-)

I use a "300x300mm Präzisionsplatten" from filafarm.de and Ikea mirrors.

Edit (11/1/17): added a Y-Endstop, a bit more adjustable then the original one. Can be used at the front and the back, see picture, and accommodates a type KW11-3Z 5A 250V microswitch as well as one with electronics around it (don't know type number, sold as an "endstop". You'll have to check for yourself if it suits yours: distances center wheel to the rail are resp. ca. 7 and 11mm vertically and ca. 3mm sideways.
11mm is a bit much, but I couldn't get it less and it works with my stuff. ;-)
Changed this text at the start a bit too.
Edit (11/23/17):

  1. added Lead_ScrewBracket(Self-Adjusting), https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2664656
  2. I don't use the - 3-wheeled Z guides (Re-D-Bot) by NickRimmer http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1802733
    any more. Reason: in practice even those 3 wheels are not used, only 2, and it is better if those 2 (the upper one at the back and the middle, resp. the lower on at the front) have as big a distance between each other as possible. So I went back to the original 4-wheel guides, where the 2 other wheels have no function, except perhaps for protecting the lead screws against accidentally lifting the bed.
  3. I always had trouble with lifting the bed, therefore I used 3 lead screws. On a good day I wanted to try 1/16 microstepping, couldn't find which bridge to remove, so replaced the drv8825 with the A4988 and everything went much better, I don't know why, but the 3rd lead screw could go out of the window. The self-adusting lead screw bracket was a result of this playing around too. ;-)

Edit (11/24/17):
Added a Flanged_Bearings_Holder. Because I went back to 2 lead screws I could go back to JonnayLin's (J-Bot) idea of coupling the 2 screws a bit via flanged bearings to having less chance they get out of kilt with each other. This holder is pushing the belt in stead of pulling, just a matter of preference for me in the given situation.
I used the usual flange bearings, a 6mm GT2 belt of 860mm with 2 pulleys, 2 M5x10 bolts with washers and hammer heads, 1 M3x30 bolt (thread up to the head) with M3 (lock) nut, 1 M3x20 bolt with washers and (lock) nut. Does not need tightening, just enough tension for the lead screws to understand each other. More is less (give the stepper motors a break). No print support needed, thanks to the diamond shapes.
Lost a lot of history here, being not relevant any more.

Edit (02-02-18): added a linear Z-axis link and picture. For a more recent overall picture I need more time, because I am in the midst of another major change. ;-)

comments.text:
I use the E1 pins for that. You can easily configure the software to that purpose with repetier-firmware, see my Configuration.h file.
I used the development version 1 of it, changed the file since then, but it clearly shows how it handles it:
"mirrorZ": "1",
"mirrorZMotor": {
"name": "Extruder 1",
"step": "ORIG_E1_STEP_PIN",
"dir": "ORIG_E1_DIR_PIN",
"enable": "ORIG_E1_ENABLE_PIN"
}
I mention it here just to check. Let the repetier website https://www.repetier.com/firmware/v092/ do that for you.

comments.text:
What if make not only one but both sides of bed carriage go along the vertical rails (like in J-bot) and also implement this:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2185911
What's you opinion?
comments.author: good_idea

comments.text:
I do not see the advantage of supporting both sides when you already have 3 lead screws for support.
I started off with the J-Bot solution, because it looked beautiful to me. But when I saw the sea-sawing, I fled to the 3-lead-screw solution. Keeping the support at both sides when using 3 lead screws could even be counterproductive: too many support points.
As for the solution with one motor: it would be ideal, but for some reason or another 2 motors weren't not enough for my printer.
I still cannot fathom why and I still hope to find the reason, the more so because others seem to succeed with one, but for now I have 3 motors working. In harmony. ;-)

remixed_from.author: t4b_
remixed_from.title: T4bee Microcopters smallest possible 2", 2.5", 3", 4" multirotors for 20x20mm FC & CCDs, Swift Mini, Micro Swift, CMOS etc.

description.text:
This is a reinforced arms version of the GreenBee 110.

I made this with the mindset that the arms must go pust the weakest/thinnest point of the frame, in order to do that on the center I designed it to still let you have access with a rounded cap (bullet?) hex screw.

Comes with a 4mm thick frame, and 2.5mm thick support on the arms.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

There is a variety of ways this can be printed:

  • As is: 21.8gms, 6.5mm thick. Now you are talking a carbon fiber equivlant if you are printing in PETG.
  • Take 1mm off the top: 21.6gms, 5.5mm thick. Gives you flatter arms that go well with soft mounted lipos on the underside
  • Take 1mm off the bottom, 3mm thick frame: 17gms.
Openscad is the bees knees. I took T4b's original cad/vector, and extruded that to a desired height. Then designed the struts on top of it.

title: Flexible Trivet gift idea for your favorite Chef

description.text:
It occurred to me that if I could put TPU in the dishwasher it would work well as a trivet. I tested this with both a pot of boiling water and a pizza stone out of the oven. Cute gift idea for the chef in your family. This one is in Filaflex.. Check out my Ninjaflex Valentine's Day Make. I wanted a more traditional design so I downloaded a public domain photo and edited in my design software.

I create these designs to encourage people to try out flexible filaments or get some new interesting colors of flexibles. For info on purchasing samples of several brands of flexible filament see flexyfilament.com

title: Bowden extruder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my own design of a spring loaded bowden extruder. It has an easy to use quick release lever for easy manual filament loading and unloading. It uses a standard 608 ball bearing and a few 3M screws. The spring I use is the same type commonly used for mounting the heatbed on 3D-printers. The tension on the spring can easily be adjusted by adjusting a screw if needed. The design is prepared for installing an optional short piece of bowden tube under the bowden coupling for guiding flexible filaments.

I made this using SketchUp, and I have included the skp-file as well. Feel free to modify if you want.

Printer:

Homebuilt core-XY printer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4mm nozzle, 0.15 mm layer height

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Printed in PLA, 3 or 4 shell layers.

author: Axbri

description.text:
The holder uses the edge of the table to ensure it doesn't move towards the printer. Requires two 608 bearings (inner diameter 8 mm, outer diameter 22mm), two 5/16'' or 8M threaded rods and 8 nuts. 4 nuts secure the lower rod, two are at the mount and two are at one end of the upper rod to prevent it from moving. The other end of the upper rod is not secured by nuts to allow for easier replacement of the filament spool.

The spool mount is by wildseyed
http://community.shapedo.com/wildseyed/osfa_filament_spool_holder

I inserted a washer into the mount before the bearing in order to prevent the inner bearing cylinder from touching the mount.

THIS IS CREATED FROM "SAVE PANGOLINS" BY AMAOCHAN. The sections were fused together when I tried to print them, so this is the exact same file but with the pieces separated. You'll need to manually trim back the socket section of each piece in order to snap the ball joint in. Note: this file does not contain the feet, which can be found at the source below. Also see source for the order of assembly.

SOURCE: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2064359

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX v2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

10%

Fitting the pieces together

Trim back the socket section of each piece in order to snap the ball joint in- I used flush cutters. (This is necessary because it was designed to be print-in-place)

comments.author: AScott94

comments.text: You should be able to separate the pieces using your slicer- in fact, that's how I made this file in the first place. Mattercontrol is a free slicer, and there is an "ungroup" feature (might be called "separate connected surfaces" in other slicers) that will allow you to select only the pieces you would like to print. You can then use the "arrange" function to center it on your print bed.
